p.seg: The gentleman says:
"In studying one must not stop."
As for blue, one takes it from the indigo plant,
but it is bluer than the indigo plant.
As for ice, water produces/constitutes it,
but it is colder than water.
A piece of wood may be straight to fit the plumbline,
but it bends to become a wheel
so that its roundness fits the compass.
The fact that even if (suīyǒu) it is dried out in the sun
it will not be straightened out again
is an effect of the bending.
Thus timber, if cut according to the plumbline, will be straight,
metal, if the whetst one is applied to it, will be sharp.
If the gentleman will study broadly
and every day he keeps investigating himself,
then his awareness will be clear,
and his actions will be without inadvertent transgressions.
Thus, if one does not climb a high mountain,
one will not understand the height of the sky;
if one does not personally get into a deep gully (xī)
one will not understand the thickness of the earth;
if one has not heard-and-learnt the transmitted words of the former kings
one does not understand the magnitude of study and inquiry.
The children of Wu and Yue, the Yi and the Mo
make the same noises when they are born
but as they grow up they have different customs.
Instruction brings this about.
The Songs [207] say:
"Oh, you gentlemen,
do not constantly relax and rest.
Be poised and respectful in your positions
and be fond of those who are correct and straight.
Then the spirits listen to you
and they will assist you with great fortune."
No spiritual force is greater than the transforming Way;
good fortune lasts no longer than the period where there is no disaster.
One may try reflecting (on something) all day,
but that is not as good as what I have studied and learnt in a moment.
One may try standing on tip-toe and looking out for something,
but that is not as good as the broad view one gets when one climbs high.
When one climbs high and waves,
it is not that one's arms get longer,
but one sees further;
if one shouts with the wind,
it is not that the sound is more intense,
but what is heard is clearer.
As for someone who borrows a cart and a horse,
it is not that he gets quicker of foot,
but he covers a thousand li;
and as for someone who borrows a boat and short oars,
it is not that gets better at swimming,
but he will (be able to) cross the Yangzi or the Yellow River.
From birth the gentleman is no different/remarkable,
but he is good at borrowing in relation to things.
In the southern regions there is a bird
and its name is the Dull Dove:
it makes its nest with feathers
ties these toget her with hair
ties them to reeds (wěi) and trumpet creeper (tiáo),
but when the storm comes the trumpet creeper snaps,
(the Dull Dove's) eggs are smashed and its young die.
It is not that the nest was not accomplished,
but the point is what it was tied to.
In the West there was a tree
and its name was Archery Trunk:
its stem is four inches long
but it grows on a high mountain
and it looks down towards a 100 fathom deep abyss.
It is not that the stem of the tree was able to increase its length,
but the point it where it is established.
Bitter fleabane (péng) gr ows among the hemp,
and without support the bitter fleabane grows straight.
White sand in black earth
will turn black together with it.
When the root of the lán-"orchid" and the scholar tree make perfume,
but if one soaks them in urine,
then the gentleman will go nowhere near it
and the ordinary person will not put it on.
It is not that the substance is not admirable,
but the point is what it was soaked in.
Therefore the gentleman, when it comes to a place to live,
will make a choice on the area,
and when it comes to travelling he will keep to men of the official class.
This is how he guards against wickedness and depravity
and keeps close to moderate and correct.
For the emergence of the categories of things
there is bound to be a beginning:original cause.
The advent of glory and disgrace
is bound to be in accordance with the moral integrity.
When meat has gone completely off it produces maggots;
and when wood is rotten it produces worms.
If one is lazy and negligent and fails to pay proper attention to one's person
then natural disasters will arise.
The strong choose their own support for strength,
and the weak choose their own fetters of weakness.
When there is wickedness and filth on the person
that is what structures/forms resentment.
If one lays out firewood evenly,
then the fire will go to the driest spot,
and if you level out the ground evenly,
then thw water will go to the wettest spot.
Shrubs and trees grow in clusters,
birds and beasts live in flocks.
Each kind of creature follows its natural kind.
Thus when the target is set,
then bows and arrows will get there;
when the trees are flourishing,
then axes will get there;
when trees give shade
then crowds of birds will rest on them;
when vinegar has turned sour/has gone off (xī suān)
blackflies with gather there.
Thus words will sometimes summon disaster,
and actions will sometimes summon personal humiliation.
The gentleman is careful about where he takes his stand.
If one amasses earth to make a hill,
then wind and rain will rise there;
if one collects water to make a deep pond,
then dragons will grow there;
if one amasses goodness to make moral charisma,
then one will naturally achieve spiritual clarity
and the mind-set of a sage will be complete.
Thus if one does not add up half-paces (kuǐ)
one has no way of reaching a distance of 1000 li;
and if one does not add up small streams,
one has no way of making the Yangzi or the sea.
When Qiji makes one leap,
he cannot cover ten paces;
a hag of a horse one has to rig up ten times,
and the success is in not giving up.
If in carving one will give up,
then one cannot even cut off a rotten piece of wood;
and if in carving one will not give up,
then even metal and stone can be engraved on (lòu 鏤).
The earthworm has neither the sharpness of claws or fangs,
nor the strength of sinews and bones,
but above it eats soil
and below it drinks from the spings,
and this is because its mental effort is unified.
The crab has eight legs and two pincers,
but without a cave by a water snake or an eel,
it has nowhere to settle down for any time.
This is because its exercise of the mind is rash-and-hasty.
And so: without dark ambition
there will be no bright clarity;
and without fumbling obscure effort
there will be no shining success.
One who walks (both parts) of a forked way will not arrive anywhere,
and one who serves two rulers will not be countenanced/ tolerated.
The eye cannot look into two directions and see clearly,
and the ear cannot listen to two things and hear clearly.
The wingless dragon has no feet but it flies along,
while the wutong squirrel has five skills eeks out a hard life in extremity.
The Songs say:
"The ring dove is in the mulberry tree,
and its young are seven.
The excellent man, my gentleman
his bearing is one,
his bearing is one.
It is as if my heart were tied to him."
And so the gentleman is tied in a knot to the one thing.
Formerly, when Huba strummed the zither
then the fish came out to listen to him;
and when Boya strummed the lute
then the six horses looked up from their feed.
Thus there is no sound that is so slight that it is not heard,
and there is no action that is so hidden that it does not take visible form.
When there is jade in a mountain shrubs and trees will flourish,
and when there are pearls in a deep pool the banks will not have withered plants.
When one does good and does not amass wickedness,
how should this not become known (in the world)?
Where should study begin?
Where should it end?
We say:
"As for its art it begins with the incantation of the classics,
and it ends with the reading out of the books of ritual.
Its moral purpose begins with that of becoming a gentleman,
and it ends with becoming a sage.
If one truly amasses/builds up and strains for long, then one will enter.
Study first ends with one's death.
Thus the art of study has a final point,
and as for its moral purpose one must not let go of it for a moment.
To work at it is to be a man,
to give up on it is to be a beast.
Thus the Documents are guidelines on political matters;
the Songs is where the sounds of the heart find their point of orientation;
the Rituals are the great basis (Yu Yue: běn 本) for the law,
and they constitute the guiding principles of (social) classifications.
Thus, when study gets to the point of ritual, then it stops.
And this is called the ultimate point of the Way and of its Power.
The earnest respectfulness and the decorum of the Rituals,
the fitting harmony of music,
the wide-ranging quality of the Songs and the Documents,
the subtlety of the Spring and Autumn Annals:
all that is between Heaven and Earth finds completion in these.
As for the way of studying of the superior man
it enters through the ear,
it sticks in the mind,
it disperses through the four limbs,
and it shows itself in his behaviour.
When he pronounces on the slightest thing,
when acting ever so slightly,
in each and every case he may serve as a model.
As for the small man's studying:
it goes in by the ear,
it goes out through the mouth,
and between mouth and ear
there are only four inches:
How is that sufficient to beautify a seven-foot body?
Those who studied in antiquity did so for their own sake,
and those who study in modern times do so for the sake of others.
The gentleman's studying
is in order to beautify his person;
and the little man's studying
is to make bird- and calf-offerings (in order to further one's career).
Now to venture information without being asked for it is presumptuousness,
and to inform on two matters when consulted on one
Being presumptuous is wrong,
and being garrulous is wrong.
The gentleman is like an echo.
In study nothing is more effective than being close to the right person.
Ritual and Music provide models but no explanations,
the Songs as well as the Documents deal with antiquity but are not incisive;
the Spring and Autumn Annals are concise but not of current relevance.
If one imitates the practice of the right person
and the explanations of the gentleman
then one will become honoured and as a result widely known,
and then one will be ever-present in one's generation.
Thus it is said:
In study nothing is more effective than be close to the right person.
No guideline of study is faster than that to develop fondness for the right person
paying due respect to ritual is the next important.
If on the one hand one cannot develop a fondness for the right person
and on the other hand one is incapable ofpaying due respect to ritual,
if he will do no more than studying sundry records,
if he will merely follow the Songs and the Documents,
then to the end of his generation and to the end of his days
he will not avoid being no more than a vulgar scholar.
But if he sets out to trace the early kings,
take goodness and rightness/ethos as his basis,
then ritual will straighten out the warp and woof, the crooked paths and the shortcuts (of action).
It is like lifting the collar of a fur coat,
bending the five fingers to get it into regular shape:???
innumerable are the elements (in the coat) that will follow suit.
If one does not take the stipulations of ritual as one's basic orientation
but carries on on the basis of the Songs and the Documents,
then that is like fathoming the depth of the Yellow river with a finger,
or like threshing broomcorn millet with a lance,
or to eat from a pot with an awl:
one cannot achieve one's purpose.
Thus, if one pays due respect to ritual,
then even if one does not quite achieve clarity on them,
one is a model member of the official class;
and if one does not pay due respect to ritual,
then even if one is analytical and discriminating,
one is still an ordinary scholar.
If someone asks about indecorous matters,
one should not tell him;
if someone informs on indecorous matters,
one should not ask questions of him;
if someone expounds indecorous matters,
one should not listen to him.
If someone has a competitive temperament,
one should not enter disputation with him.
Thus only when someone has arrived by the right Way
only then should one receive him,
and when he has arrived by the wrong Way, then one should avoid him.
Thus only when someone is ritually reverential in his demeanour,
only then can one discuss with him the methods of the Way;
only when someone's formulations are smooth,
only then can one speak to him of the principles of the Way;
only when someone's facial expression is acquiescent,
only then can one speak to him on the ultimate points of the Way.
And so to speak to someone to whom one ought not quite to speak to,
that is called being presumptuous;
not speaking to someone to whom one ought to speak,
that is called secretiveness;
and to speak to someone whithout observing his facial expression,
that is called blindness.
Thus the gentleman is not presumptuous, not secretive and not blind
and he is careful about the persons (he deals with).
The Songs say:
"Those who are not over-eager and not remiss,
these are given presents by the Son of Heaven."
That refers to this point.
If one misses one shot in a hundred,
one does not deserve to be called good at archery;
if one does not reach the 1000 li target by half a pace,
one does not deserve to be called good at driving carriages;
if someone is not fully conversant with moral rules and categories,
if his humaneness and ethos is not unified,
then he does not deserve to be called good at studying.
As for study,
it is inherently the study to unify things.
To get it wrong one time,
and to get it right the next time,
that is the way of the man in the street.
Those who are good are few,
those who are not good are in the majority:
Jie, Zhou and the Robber Zhi are cases in point.
Only when one is complete and exhaustive,
only then is one a devotee of study.
The gentleman knows that what is incomplete and less than exquisite does not deserve to be regarded as admirable.
Thus he will learn by heart many things in order to find the unity among them;
he will reflect and research in order to get to the bottom of things;
he will imitate the right person in order to practise what he has learnt,
he will remove those who do harm to what he has learnt in order to nourish it.
He brings it about that the eye does not want to see anything other than this,
brings it about that his ears do not want to hear anything other than this,
brings it about that his mouth does not want to speak of anything other than this,
brings it about that the mind does not want to think of anything other than this.
When he gets to this ultimate point,
he grows fond of what he is studying.
His eyes love it more than the five colours,
his ears love it more than the five tones,
his mouth loves it more than the five tastes,
his heart finds it more profitable than governing all under Heaven.
Therefore constellations of power and profit cannot make him tilt in any direction,
the common crowd cannot change him,
all under Heaven cannot make him waver.
In life he follows this,
in death he follows this.
Now this is called the grasp on inner power.
Only when one has a grasp on inner power can one settle down,
only when one can settle down can one respond.
When one can settle down and rspond,
then such a person is called an "accomplished person".
Heaven sees his luminosity,
Earth sees the light he radiates.
The gentleman sets store by this accomplished completeness.
When one sees something good
then, carefully, one must certainly examine oneself;
and if one sees something bad,
then, saddened, one must certainly investigate oneself.
When a good point is in one's person,
then, positively, one must certainly like oneself;
and if a bad point is in one's person,
then, negatively/darkly one must certainly dislike oneself.
Thus he who criticises one and who is right,
he is one's master.
and he who approves of one and is right,
he is one's friend;
but the person who fawns on me,
he is one's malefactor.
Thus the gentleman holds his teacher in high esteem is is close to friends
but he feels extreme hatred for malefactors.
He is fond of what is good, and unsatiable in this regard,
he accepts remonstration and is able to take heed.
Even if he wished he did not advance,
would he be able to get his way? (Surely not!)
The little man is the opposite of this:
When he is wreaking havoc
then he hates others disapproving of him;
and when he is showing incompetent results
then he wants others to regard him as talented.
His heart is like that of a tiger or wolf,
his actions may be like those wild birds and beasts,
but he still hates it when others regard him as a malefactor.
Those who flatter them he will keep close to,
and those who remonstrate and make objections he will keep at a distance;
correcting errors he regards as laughable,
and showing the utmost devotion he regards as malefaction.
Even if he wanted to avoid ruin,
how could he achieve that?
The Songs say:
They band together, they slander,
and things are surely in a highly grievous state.
When they give good advice
then they all go against it;
and when one gives bad advice
they will all follow it."
That is to the point.
If in everything one follows the standard of goodness
to control one's vital energies and to nourish life,
then one will succeed Péngzǔ;/
and if one theregy cultivates ones's person and strengthens oneself
one will be become the equal of Yáo and Yǔ./
(That standard) is suitable for timely success/
is of use for living under hard conditions./
That (standard) is ritual propriety and good faith.
As for all things with blood and breath, thought, and forethought/
when they follow ritual their dispositions will achieve their aim,
if they do not follow ritual then there will be chaos and dissoluteness
As for eating and drinking, clothes, life style and action,
if they follow ritual then they are in harmony,
and if they do not follow ritual one hits snags and catches diseases;
As for facial expression, attitude, entering and withdrawing, gait,
if these follow ritual they are elegant
and it they do not follow ritual, then they are barbarian, contrary, vulgar and they will be wild.
Thus if man is without ritual he will not live,/
if an undertaking is without ritual it will not succeed,/
if a state or a clan is without ritual it will not hav peace./
The Songs say:
"The rituals and ceremonies are all measured,
and so their every laughter and chatter is adequate."
That is to the point.
To guide others with good points is called teaching,
and to accord with others on good points is called obedience;
to guide others with bad points is called (active) ingratiating flattery,
to accord with others on bad points is called (reactive) obliging sycophancy.
To consider as right what is right and as wrong what is wrong is called knowing;
and to consider as wrong what is right and as right what is wrong is being ignorant.
Hurting the excellent is slander,
harming the excellent is malefaction.
Calling what is right right,
and calling what is wrong wrong,
that is called straightness.
Stealing goods is called robbery/malefaction;
concealed action is called fraud;
having a loose tongue is called boasting.
Being unsteady in one's choices is called unsteadiness,
and guarding profit at the cost of ethos is extreme malefaction.
Having heard-and-learnt much is called being broad,
and having heard-and-learnt little is called being shallow;
having seen much is called being broadly cultured,
and having seen little is called being vulgar.
Having difficulty in advancing is called being slow,
and forgetting easily is called being leaky.
Keeping a few things in principled orderod called being well-ordered,
The Art of Controlling the Vital Energies and Nourishing the MIND
If the blood humour is too strong and robust,
calm it with balance and harmony.
If his thinking is too profound
unify them with ease and sincerity.
If the impulse to daring and bravery is too fierce and violent,
stay it with guidance and instruction.
If the quickness of the mind and the fluency of the tongue are too punctilious and sharp
moderate them through proper behaviour.
if the narrowness of mind is petty,
broaden it with liberality and magnanimity.
What is base and low from greed for selfish gain,
lift up with a sense of high purpose.
What is common and mediocre, worthless and undisciplined,
overcome with the help of teachers and friends.
What is negligent and self-indulgent, frivolous and heedless,
warn against with omens and portents.
What is simpleminded but sincere, upright and diligent,
consolidate with ritual and music.
(What is...), make comprehensive with thought and inquiry.
In summary, of all the methods of controlling the vital energies and nourishing the mind,
none is more direct than proceeding according to ritual principles,
none more essential than obtaining a good teacher,
and none more intelligent than unifying one's likes.
Truly this procedure may properly be called "the method of controlling the vital breath and nourishing the mind."
If a person cultivates his will and sense of purpose, he can take more pride in them than in riches and eminence.
If he gives due weight to the Way and what is congruent with it, he will have slight regard fo kings and dukes.
Absorbed in the examination of his inner self, he will scorn mere external things.
A tradition expresses this:
The gentleman works external things;
the petty man works for external things.
Do whatever causes the mind to be serene,
though it gives the body toil, and whatever causes one's sense for what is right to develop,
though it diminishes the concern for profit.
Serving a disruptive lord and being successful
is not as good as serving an impoverished lord and being obedient in such service.
Accordingly, just as a good farmer does not fail to plow because of flooding and drought,
so, too, the scholar and gentleman do not neglect the Way because of poverty and want.
If your deportment is respectful and reverent, your heart loyal and faithful,
if you use only those methods sanctioned by ritual principles and moral duty,and if your emotional disposition is one of loving care for others,
then though you travel throughout the empire,
and though you find yourself reduced to living among the Four Yi tribes,
everyone would consider you to be an honourable person.
If you strive to be the first to undertake toilsome and bitter tasks
and can leave pleasant and rewarding tasks to others,
if you are proper and decent, sincere, and trustworhthy,
if you take responsibility and oversee it meticulously,
then you may travel right across the world
and even if you find yourself in troublesome circumstances among Four Barbarians,
everyone would be willing to entrust you with official duties.
But if one's deportment is insolent and headstrong,
and one's heart is deceitful,
if one's philosophy is that of Shèn Dào and of Mòzǐ
and one's subtle essences are all confused and murky,
then when one travels all over the world
even if one gets to the Four Outer Regions,
Everyone will rate one low.
If you are evasive and timorous, if you shun and avoid toilsome and bitter tasks,
if you are cleverly pervasive and shrewdly eager, adaptable and accommodating, in seeking out rewarding and pleasant tasks,
if you are depraved and perverted,
if you are not diligent and do not conscientiously perform your regular tasks and duties,
then though you travel throughout the world,
even to the farthest directions,
everyone will cast you out.
He does not walk with his hands folded respectfully before him
because he fears tha he may soil his sleeves in the mud.
Nor does he walk with his head bowed
because he is worried that he may collide with something.
He is not the first to lower his eyes when he encounters a colleague
out of fear and trepidation.
The scholar behaves in this way because he desires only to cultivate his own person
and incur no blame from the common folk of his neighborhood.
Qiji could cover 1.000 li in a single day,
but if a worn-out nag takes the journey in ten stages,
then it, too, can cover the distance.
Are you going to try to exhaust the inexhaustible
and pursue the boundless?
If you do, then though you break your bones and wear out your flesh in the attempt,
in the end it will be impossible to reach your goal.
But if you undertake a journey that has an end,
then though it be 1.000 li or more,
whether quickley or slowly, before others or after them,
how could you be unable to reach te goal!
Will you be one of those who unwittingly marches along the road
attempting to exhaust the inexhaustible
and pursue the boundless?
Or will you rather undertake only what has an end?
Such problems as "hard and white," "idendity and difference," and "dimensions and dimensionless"
are not inherently unexaminable,
but the gentleman nonetheless does not engage in debate concerning them
because he places them beyond the boundary of his endeavors.
It is not that performing strange and extraordinary feats
is not difficult,
nonetheless the gentleman does not perform them
because he places them beyond the boundary of his endeavors.
Hence is said: Learning is slow-going
That stopping place awaits us.
If we set out for it and proceed toward the goal,
though some will move quickly and others slowly, though some will lead the way and others follow,
how could we all not be able to reach the same goal!
Thus, moving ahead step by step and not resting,
a lame turtle can go 1.000 li.
Pile up earth basket by basket and do not quit,
and in the end a high mound will be completed.
If you dam up their sources
and open up their sluices,
even the Yangzi River can be drained dry.
With one advancing and another retreating,
one moving to the left and another to the right,
the six horses would get nowhere.
Surely the natural abilities of men do not differ so widely
as a lame turtle and six horses,
yet the lame turtle reaches the goal
and the six horses do not.
There is no other reason for this
than that the one acts
and the other does not.
Though the Way is near,
if you do not travel along it, you will not reach the end.
Though the task is small,
if it is not acted upon, it will not be completed.
One who spends many days in idleness
will not excel others by much.
He who acts from a love of the model
is a scholar.
He who embodies it with a firm sense
is a gentleman.
He who has an understanding of it that is acute without limit
is a sage.
If a man lacks the model,
he acts with rash and aimless confusion.
If he possesses the model, but has no recognition of what is congruent with it,
he nervously looks about, anxiously wondering what to do.
Only after he has come to rely on the model
and then gone on to penetrate deeply into its application through analogical extension to other categories and types of things
does he act with gentle warmth and calm confidence.
It is through ritual that the individual is rectified.
It is by means of a teacher that ritual is rectified.
If there were no ritual, how could the individual be rectified?
If there were not teachers, how could you know which ritual is correct?
When what ritual mandates, you make so in your conduct,
then your emotions will find peace in ritual.
When what your teacher says you say also,
then your knowledge will be like that of your teacher.
When your emotions find peace in ritual
and your knowledge is like that of your teacher
then you will become a sage.
Hence to oppose ritual
is the same as lacking a model.
To oppose your teacher
is the same as being without a teacher.
Not to hold correct your teacher and the model,
but to prefer instead to rely on your own notions
is to employ a blind man to differentiate colors
or a deaf person to distinguish sounds -
you have nothing with which to reject confusion and error.
Therefore one who is in the process of learning
is one who learns of ritual principles and of the model. [Study is a method for propriety.??? CH]
The teacher is one who makes his own person an erect gnomon indicating the proper standard of deportment
and who values what is at peace with him.
An Ode says:
Not from knowledge, not from wisdon, //
were you obedient to the Di Ancestor's rules. //
this expresses my meaning.
If you are straightforward and diligent, obedient and respectful of your elders,
you are properly called a "good youth."
If you add to these a love of learning
combined with modesty and earnestness,
then you may properly be considered a gentleman.
But if you are evasive, timorous, and shirk your duties,
if you lack any sense of modesty or shame and have an inordinate fondness for food and drink as well,
you are properly called a "despicable youth."
If you add to these profligacy, cruelty, disobedience,
treachery, malice, and disrespectfulness to elders,
then you are properly called an "ill-omened youth."
Although you may suffer dismemberment or death as punishment, it is entirely proper that it should be so.
Mature adults will flock to one who treats the elderly as they should be treated.
Successful men will congregate around one who does not place hardships on those already having difficulties.
If one conducts himself in obscurity and is kind when no recognition will result,
then the worthy and unworthy alike will unite about him.
A person who possess these three qualities,
though he be sent a greatly inauspicious omen,
would Heaven have wrought his ruin?
The gentleman treats summarily the pursuit of profit
but is alert to keeping out of harm's way.
He is apprehensive about avoiding disgrace
but is courageous in conducting himself in accordance with the Way and the requirements of reason.
In the times of hardship and poverty, the gentleman broadens his sense of purpose.
In the times of properity and honour, he comports himself with respectfulness.
When tranquil and at ease, his blood humour is not enfeebled.
In times of fatigue and exhaustion, hes appearance is not slovenly.
He does not commit the excess of snatching things back out of anger
or that of giving things away out of joy.
The gentleman can broaden his senseof purpose even in times of hardship and poverty
because he exalts the principle of humanity.
He is able to comport himself with respectfulness toward others even when he is wealthy and honored
because he deprecates the power and influence that accompany them.
His blood humour is not enfeebled when he is tranquil and as ease
because he is restrained by natural order.
His appearance is not slovenly in times of fatigue and exhaustion
because he is fond of good form.
He does not commit the excess of snatching things back out of anger
or that of giving things away out of joy
because the model triumphs over merely private interests.
One of the Documents says:
Nothing have which predilections create, //
Follow the way of the King. //

The Great Distinction Between Honor and Disgrace
and the Invariable Condition of Security and Benefit and of Danger and Harm.
Those who put first what is just and later matters of benefit are honorable;
those who put first what is beneficial and later what is just are shameful.
Those who are honorable always gain success;
those who are shameful invariably fail.
the successful always administer others;
failures are always administered by others.
Such is the great distinction between honor and disgrace.
Those who are natural and honest invariably obtain security and benefit;
those who are profligate and cruel invariably obtain danger and harm.
Those who have gained security and benefits are always happy and relaxed.
Those who feel endangered and threatened with harm are always melancholy and insecure.
Those who are happy and relaxed always live to great age;
those who are melancholy and insecure always are cut down while youths.
Such are the invariable conditions, respectively, of security and benefit and of danger and harm.
